title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To study the influence of the local microenvironment on tumour invasion
outcome: we applied spatially resolved transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) to a transgenic zebrafish model of BRAFV600E-driven melanoma
predicted_context: Tumour cells located at the physical interface between the tumour and the surrounding tissue are exposed to distinct mechanical forces, such as confinement, which often result in morphological adaptations (e.g., nuclear deformation) distinct from those seen in the tumour core.
predicted_outcome: We will utilize a zebrafish melanoma model to image and compare the nuclear morphology and transcriptional profiles of tumour cells located at the tumour-microenvironment interface versus those located within the tumour body.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Across fish, we found a conserved ‘interface’ transcriptional cell state that occurs where tumour cells invade into the microenvironment 6 (12.1% of zebrafish tumour cells; Fig. 1a)
context: Tumours from this model frequently invade into adjacent tissues, including the underlying dermis and muscle
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is a well-established principle in cancer biology that spatial positioning defines cellular identity, as the tumor border imposes unique physical and chemical cues (such as mechanical confinement) distinct from the tumor core.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that this distinct transcriptional signature is not random but is spatially induced, representing a specific invasive phenotype triggered by the interaction between the cancer cells and the surrounding tissue microenvironment.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To investigate whether these interface cells occur in patients
context: a recently published human melanoma scRNA-seq dataset of 7,186 tumour and stromal cells from 31 patients with untreated or immunotherapy-resistant melanoma7
outcome: we analysed a recently published human melanoma scRNA-seq dataset of 7,186 tumour and stromal cells from 31 patients with untreated or immunotherapy-resistant melanoma7 (Fig. 1b and Extended Data Fig. 1a). We scored tumour cells for the relative expression of interface genes from our zebrafish transcriptomic datasets
predicted_context: Since the interface phenotype identified in the zebrafish model is defined by both a specific spatial location (the tumor boundary) and a distinct transcriptional signature (neuronal/invasive gene program), validating this in human pathology requires a method that preserves tissue architecture while profiling gene expression.
predicted_outcome: Perform spatial transcriptomics on human melanoma samples to spatially map the expression of the neuronal-like gene program at the interface between the tumour and the surrounding microenvironment.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content:
a subpopulation of human tumour cells
highly upregulated interface markers (12.3% of tumour cells; Fig. 1c and Extended Data Fig. 1b), mostly from immunotherapy-resistant patients
(Extended Data Fig. 1d–f)
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is established in this study that mechanical confinement at the tumor interface triggers phenotype switching via HMGB2, forcing cells into a slow-cycling, invasive state that is inherently more resistant to therapeutics compared to the proliferative state.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the mechanically induced 'interface' phenotype is clinically relevant, implying that microenvironmental confinement significantly contributes to the persistence of melanoma cells and failure of immunotherapy in human patients.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To better understand the nature of these cells
context: A previous study defined at least four cell states that encompass the melanoma differentiation trajectory (melanocytic, transitory, neural crest-like and undifferentiated)
outcome:
we compared our interface population to human melanoma cell states...We scored tumour and interface cells for the relative expression of gene modules encompassing the entire melanoma cell differentiation trajectory and classified cells into
each of the four states on the basis of their expression of gene modules annotated for that state2.
predicted_context: Characterizing the molecular identity and heterogeneity of tumor subpopulations requires high-resolution gene expression analysis to identify specific transcriptional programs associated with distinct cellular states.
predicted_outcome: we performed spatial and single-cell transcriptomics.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Although tumour cells were relatively evenly distributed between the four cell states, interface cells showed clear upregulation of genes characteristic of the undifferentiated state (Fig. 1d,e and Extended Data Fig. 1c). ... Interface cells downregulated MITF and SOX10 and upregulated SOX9 (Fig. 1f and Extended Data Fig. 1g). Classical melanocyte pigmentation genes were minimally expressed by interface cells relative to the tumour bulk, including MITF (log2 fold change (FC) = −5.19), TYRP1 (log2FC = −7.75) and PMEL (log2FC = −8.78) (Fig. 1f, Extended Data Fig. 1g and Supplementary Table 1). Unexpectedly, interface cells also upregulated genes involved in neuronal development, including SOX11 (log2FC = 5.15), NNAT (log2FC = 8.61), NEUROD1 (log2FC = 6.22) and NEFM (log2FC = 6.19) (Fig. 1g and Supplementary Table 1). Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) revealed that transcriptional programs linked to cell fate specification and neuronal development were highly enriched in interface cells (Fig. 1h,i).
context: Melanoma behaviour is regulated by phenotype switching, in which cells transition between differentiated/proliferative and undifferentiated/invasive states. The transition between the proliferative and invasive states is regulated by the transcription factors MITF, SOX9 and SOX10, among others8. MITF and SOX10 regulate melanocyte differentiation and proliferation9,10, whereas SOX9 is associated with the undifferentiated invasive state11
outcome: These data indicate that interface cells adopt an invasive state with markers of neuronal development.
predicted_context: It is a well-established principle in melanoma biology that 'phenotype switching' involves the loss of lineage-specific differentiation markers (dedifferentiation) and the reactivation of embryonic neural crest programs, which functions as a mechanism to facilitate plasticity and invasion.
predicted_outcome: These findings suggest that the specific microenvironmental conditions at the tumor interface induce a lineage regression, driving cells away from the melanocytic identity toward a dedifferentiated, invasive neuronal-like phenotype.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To examine factors within the local TME that may drive the interface state
outcome: we performed histology on tissue sections from our transgenic zebrafish melanoma model, focusing on the invasive front.
predicted_context: Physical deformation of the nucleus, specifically the acquisition of an elliptical shape, is a well-established cellular response to mechanical confinement and compressive forces exerted by the surrounding tissue microenvironment.
predicted_outcome: Perform morphological analysis on zebrafish melanoma tumors to quantify and compare the nuclear aspect ratio of tumor cells located at the tumor-microenvironment interface versus those within the tumor body.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Tumour cells invading into the TME showed elongated nuclei compared with the bulk tumour mass (Fig. 1j,k)
context:
A previous study showed that tumour nuclei become highly elongated when squeezing through mechanically
restrictive environments12.
outcome: Although numerous factors probably influence tumour invasion, we hypothesized that mechanical forces exerted on the cell/nucleus may cause stable changes in gene expression and tumour cell behaviour.
predicted_context: It is established that nuclear deformation, such as the transition to an elliptical or elongated shape, is a morphological signature of cells subjected to physical compression or mechanical confinement by adjacent tissues.
predicted_outcome: This implies that the cells at the tumor-microenvironment interface are experiencing significant mechanical confinement forces, identifying physical stress as a distinct environmental cue present at the invasion front but absent in the bulk tumor.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To test this hypothesis
context: a system to confine human melanoma cells ... in vitro at predefined heights ... using a polydimethylsiloxane piston and micropatterned coverslips13.
outcome: we adapted a system to confine human melanoma cells (A375 cell line) in vitro at predefined heights (3 µm) using a polydimethylsiloxane piston and micropatterned coverslips13 (Fig. 1l).
predicted_context: Isolating the effects of physical forces from biochemical signaling in the tumor microenvironment requires a controlled in vitro system that can impose precise physical constraints on cell nucleus geometry to mimic the compression found at the tumor interface.
predicted_outcome: Culture melanoma cells within microfluidic channels of defined sub-nuclear heights (e.g., 3-10 µm) to induce mechanical confinement, followed by the assessment of HMGB2 nuclear dynamics using fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) and transcriptomic profiling to detect the induction of invasive gene signatures.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
confined cells did not upregulate apoptosis markers cleaved caspase-3, annexin V or cleaved
PARP (Extended Data Fig. 2a–f).
outcome: Confinement in vitro was not cytotoxic
predicted_context: Cleaved caspase-3, annexin V, and cleaved PARP are widely established as canonical molecular biomarkers specifically indicative of the execution phase of apoptosis (programmed cell death).
predicted_outcome: This demonstrates that the mechanical confinement experienced by the tumour cells is sublethal and tolerated, ruling out cell death as a confounding factor and supporting the conclusion that the cells survive the stress to undergo a functional phenotypic transition.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
Post-confinement, cells recovered typical morphology within 24 h without widespread cell death (Extended
Data Fig. 2g).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: True cellular plasticity is defined by the ability of cells to reversibly alter their phenotype in response to environmental stimuli, distinguishing adaptive switching from permanent differentiation or toxicity-induced damage.
predicted_outcome: This indicates that the morphological and phenotypic changes driven by mechanical confinement are transient and reversible, confirming that the observed state represents a plastic adaptation rather than an irreversible injury or fixed cell fate.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To profile confinement-induced changes in gene expression
outcome: we confined A375 cells for approximately 18 h and performed bulk RNA-seq
predicted_context: Since mechanical confinement forces, indicated by nuclear deformation, are most prominent at the interface between the tumor and the surrounding microenvironment, and distinct phenotypic states (proliferative vs. invasive) likely correspond to specific transcriptomic signatures based on their spatial location.
predicted_outcome: Perform spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) on melanoma samples to spatially map and identify gene programs enriched in cells located at the tumor-stroma interface compared to the tumor core.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Principal component analysis revealed considerabletranscriptional alterations induced by confinement (Fig. 1m and Supplementary Table 2).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is well established that significant separation and clustering in Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of RNA-sequencing data indicate fundamental, global shifts in gene expression profiles rather than isolated regulatory events.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that mechanical confinement acts as a potent extrinsic driver capable of inducing a comprehensive reprogramming of the cellular transcriptome, thereby establishing a distinct molecular phenotype.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Similar to human interface cells, confined cells upregulated several neuronal pathways (Fig. 1n and Supplementary Table 2). We calculated the overlap between the human interface gene signature and the confined melanoma gene signature (Extended Data Fig. 2h and Supplementary Table 3). Pathway analysis showed that many of the co-regulated genes were related to neuronal development (Extended Data Fig. 2i and Supplementary Table 3).
outcome: These data indicate that confinement causes interface cells to adopt a neuronal identity.
predicted_context: It is well established that melanoma cells originate from the neural crest lineage and possess high plasticity, often allowing them to reactivate ancestral embryonic programs shared with neurons during dedifferentiation or state transitions.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that mechanical confinement specifically triggers a lineage-specific form of phenotype switching, wherein tumor cells revert to a pseudo-neuronal, invasive state to facilitate survival and migration in restrictive microenvironments.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: confinement causes interface cells to adopt a neuronal identity
context: Neuronal development relies on microtubule (MT) architecture, influencing almost every aspect of neuronal structure and function14. The cytoskeleton often transmits force within and between cells and remodels in response to mechanical stimuli15. Recent reports indicate that the MT cytoskeleton is stabilized by force to protect confined cells from damage16.
outcome:
We hypothesized that melanoma cells hijack neuronal
mechanisms to allow them to invade into the mechanically confined microenvironment ... confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons
predicted_context: It is established that mechanical cues from the microenvironment can induce chromatin remodelling and alter the binding dynamics of nuclear proteins, such as DNA-bending factors, to regulate cell state transitions.
predicted_outcome: Consequently, this suggests that mechanical confinement triggers a phenotypic switch by upregulating HMGB2 and increasing its chromatin residence time, thereby activating a transcriptional program characteristic of neuronal invasion and drug resistance.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We hypothesized that melanoma cells hijack neuronal mechanisms to allow them to invade into the mechanically confined microenvironment ... confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons
outcome: We used our in vitro confinement system to characterize how force remodels the MT cytoskeleton by imaging A375 cells labelled with the MT vital dye SiR-tubulin
predicted_context: Neurons rely on a specialized, stabilized microtubule cytoskeleton, characterized by high levels of acetylation (e.g., acetylated alpha-tubulin), to maintain structural integrity and facilitate axonal transport during extension through complex tissue environments.
predicted_outcome: Perform immunofluorescence staining using antibodies against acetylated alpha-tubulin to visualize the cytoskeletal architecture and quantify the presence of stabilized microtubule cages around the nuclei of confined melanoma cells.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confinement extensively remodelled the MT cytoskeleton; within 2–4 h, curved MTs began encircling the cell and nuclear periphery (Fig. 2a,b).
context:
This was reminiscent of a previous study that showed that MTs bend to prevent buckling
or rupture in response to force16
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is established that during cell migration through spatially restricted environments, the nucleus is susceptible to mechanical damage and rupture, necessitating the formation of a perinuclear microtubule network to serve as a protective mechanical shield.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the observed cytoskeletal reorganization is an adaptive response to mechanical confinement, where the cell constructs a structural cage to preserve nuclear integrity against compressive forces.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We also observed loss of a central MT organizing centre with radial MTs
context: reminiscent of neurons with centrosome-independent MT organization14,17.
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: The presence of a distinct microtubule organizing center (MTOC) with a radial array is structurally characteristic of stationary, proliferative cells, whereas its disassembly is a prerequisite for the profound cytoskeletal reorganization required during cell state transitions.
predicted_outcome: This cytoskeletal dismantling indicates that the cells are exiting the proliferative state to facilitate the assembly of the protective acetylated tubulin cage, a structural hallmark of the confinement-induced invasive neuronal phenotype.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Curved MTs, such as those we observed in confined cells
context:
Acetylated tubulin mediates neuronal architecture and function and marks axonal MTs18. Tubulin acetylation stabilizes MTs and thus the cell against mechanical pressure19. Curved MTs, such as those we observed in confined cells (Fig. 2a,b), are also indicative of long-lived,
stabilized MTs19.
outcome: enrichment of acetylated tubulin at the tumour border
predicted_context: Microtubules typically function as stiff, compression-bearing struts that can buckle or bend to store elastic potential energy when subjected to high physical loads.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the observed curvature is a response to mechanical confinement, indicating the microtubules have accumulated bending energy to reinforce the cell and protect the nucleus from external pressure.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: enrichment of acetylated tubulin at the tumour border?
outcome: We performed immunofluorescence on sections from adult fish with transgenic BRAFV600E-driven melanomas
predicted_context: Acetylated tubulin is a marker of stable microtubules, which form a protective cage around the nucleus to maintain genomic integrity and facilitate migration when cells are subjected to mechanical confinement or physical squeezing at tissue interfaces.
predicted_outcome: Perform immunofluorescence microscopy on melanoma tumour sections using antibodies against acetylated tubulin to visualize and quantify signal intensity in cells at the tumour-microenvironment interface relative to the tumour core.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confining A375 cells in vitro also resulted in significant upregulation of acetylated tubulin (P = 6.86 × 10−12; Fig. 2f–h). Acetylated tubulin filaments in unconfined cells were typically short and linear, whereas in confined cells, acetylated tubulin filaments were longer and more curved—again indicative of stabilization (Fig. 2f,g).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: Tubulin acetylation is a well-established post-translational modification that marks long-lived, stable microtubules, providing structural reinforcement and resistance to mechanical stress compared to dynamic microtubules.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that mechanical confinement acts as a physical cue triggering cytoskeletal remodeling, specifically inducing microtubule stabilization to likely provide the structural resilience or nuclear protection required for survival and invasion in compressed microenvironments.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We noticed that in confined cells, the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear (Fig. 2f,g)
context:
As the stiffest and largest organelle, the nucleus is vulnerable to confinement-induced
stress, with confined migration often causing nuclear envelope rupture and DNA damage20,21. During migration through confined spaces, neurons assemble a perinuclear network of acetylated tubulin to protect the nucleus22,23.
outcome: hypothesized that this network may provide structural support to the nucleus
predicted_context: It is established that acetylation stabilizes microtubules, making them more resistant to mechanical breakage, and that perinuclear microtubule cages serve to reinforce the nucleus and protect it from rupture during migration through narrow, confined spaces.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the spatial reorganization of the tubulin network into a perinuclear cage is a specific structural adaptation intended to shield the nucleus from deformation and mechanical damage caused by the external pressure of the confined microenvironment.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
We confirmed the stability of the perinuclear MT
network
context: nocodazole, which induces MT disassembly through an acetylation-independent mechanism24...Acetylated MTs are resistant to nocodazole19
outcome: by treating confined cells with nocodazole
predicted_context: Stable microtubules are biophysically distinguished from dynamic ones by their resistance to depolymerizing agents and are frequently marked by post-translational modifications such as acetylation.
predicted_outcome: Treat cells with the microtubule-destabilizing drug nocodazole and subsequently perform immunofluorescence imaging to demonstrate that the perinuclear microtubule cage remains intact while dynamic microtubules depolymerize.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Nocodazole (1 µM) induced the disassembly of almost all non-modified tubulin filaments in both unconfined and confined cells (Fig. 2i,j). Although unconfined nocodazole treated cells exhibited minimal acetylated tubulin, many confined nocodazole-treated cells contained a perinuclear acetylated tubulin cage (Fig. 2i,j).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is well established that tubulin acetylation contributes to microtubule stability, rendering filaments resistant to depolymerization agents like nocodazole, whereas non-modified microtubules remain dynamic and susceptible to disassembly.
predicted_outcome: Therefore, the persistence of the perinuclear acetylated tubulin cage in confined cells following nocodazole treatment demonstrates that mechanical confinement induces the formation of a highly stable, chemically resistant microtubule structure that is distinct from the dynamic cytoskeleton observed in unconfined cells.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Which acetyltransferase that responds to mechanical stress in melanoma cells by stabilizing the tubulin cytoskeleton.
outcome: We generated a stable A375 cell line, in which the main eukaryotic tubulin acetyltransferase (ATAT1) was inactivated using CRISPR (Extended Data Fig. 3a,b),
predicted_context: Mechanical confinement forces tumor cells to undergo significant deformation, requiring a reinforced cytoskeleton to protect the nucleus from rupture. Acetylation of alpha-tubulin (specifically at Lysine 40) is a well-established post-translational modification that imparts flexibility and mechanical stability to microtubules, and this modification is primarily catalyzed by the enzyme ATAT1 (alpha-tubulin acetyltransferase 1).
predicted_outcome: Culture melanoma cells under conditions of mechanical confinement (using microfluidic channels or confinement devices), measure the protein expression levels of ATAT1 and acetylated tubulin using Western blotting and immunofluorescence, and perform loss-of-function experiments (siRNA or CRISPR knockout of ATAT1) to verify if the formation of the protective tubulin cage is dependent on this specific enzyme.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We generated a stable A375 cell line, in which the main eukaryotic tubulin acetyltransferase (ATAT1) was inactivated using CRISPR (Extended Data Fig. 3a,b), and found that this almost completely abolished acetylated tubulin, including the perinuclear network (Extended Data Fig. 3c–e).
outcome: This indicates that ATAT1 is the acetyltransferase that responds to mechanical stress in melanoma cells by stabilizing the tubulin cytoskeleton.
predicted_context: It is established that ATAT1 mediates the acetylation of alpha-tubulin, a post-translational modification necessary for stabilizing microtubules and forming the perinuclear cage structure that protects the nucleus from mechanical damage during invasion.
predicted_outcome: This confirms that ATAT1 is essential for the formation and maintenance of the perinuclear acetylated tubulin network, validating the cell line as a model to test the necessity of this mechanical protection mechanism in melanoma phenotype switching.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear
context: In addition to acetylation, MTs exhibit a variety of post-translational modifications (PTMs), including tyrosination, glutamylation, glycylation and methylation, which influence MT stability25.
outcome: clarify the composition of the perinuclear tubulin network
predicted_context: The study establishes that interface cells acquire an acetylated tubulin cage specifically to act as a protective structural mechanism for the nucleus during migration under mechanical confinement.
predicted_outcome: This localization suggests that the network functions as a mechanical shield, reinforcing the nucleus against physical deformation and damage as invasive cells squeeze through restrictive tissue barriers.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To clarify the composition of the perinuclear tubulin network
outcome: we used immunofluorescence to characterize MT PTMs in confined melanoma cells
predicted_context: Microtubules undergo specific post-translational modifications, such as acetylation, which serve as markers for stable, long-lived structures often associated with mechanical resistance and nuclear protection.
predicted_outcome: Perform immunofluorescence staining using antibodies specific for acetylated tubulin and tyrosinated tubulin to visualize and distinguish the specific microtubule isoforms forming the perinuclear cage.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: most MTs in confined and unconfined A375 cells were highly tyrosinated (Extended Data Fig. 4a–d)
context: Detyrosination has been linked to stabilized MTs26
outcome: probably owing to the high concentrations of tyrosine and tyrosinase in melanoma27
predicted_context: Tyrosination of alpha-tubulin is a post-translational modification that typically marks dynamic, newly polymerized microtubules, whereas acetylation usually identifies stable, long-lived microtubule structures.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the global dynamic instability of the microtubule network is maintained even under mechanical stress, implying that the specific accumulation of acetylated tubulin observed in confined cells represents a targeted structural adaptation (such as a nuclear cage) rather than a complete global shift toward microtubule stability.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Although confined perinuclear MTs were occasionally tyrosinated and rarely detyrosinated (Extended Data Fig. 4a–d), there was no specific enrichment of these PTMs in the perinuclear network, as observed for acetylated MTs. Similar results were observed for poly-glutamylated MTs (Extended Data Fig. 4e,f). No polyglycylated MTs were found in either condition (Extended Data Fig. 4g,h).
outcome: This indicates that acetylation is the primary PTM mediating the assembly and/or stability of the perinuclear tubulin network
predicted_context: Microtubule acetylation is a post-translational modification specifically associated with increased mechanical stability, flexibility, and resistance to breakage (long-lived microtubules), whereas other modifications like tyrosination typically mark dynamic or labile microtubules.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the mechanical confinement of melanoma cells does not induce a generalized accumulation of microtubule modifications, but rather drives a specific structural adaptation—the formation of a stable, acetylated perinuclear cage—to mechanically protect the nucleus during invasion.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
These results indicate that confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons ...Acetylated tubulin
filaments in unconfined cells were typically short and linear, whereas in confined cells, acetylated tubulin filaments were longer and more curved—again indicative of stabilization ...We noticed that in confined cells, the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear (Fig. 2f,g)
outcome: These data indicate that confined melanoma cells assemble a stable perinuclear tubulin network to reinforce the nucleus against mechanical stress, similar to neurons.
predicted_context: It is well established that tubulin acetylation serves as a marker for stable, long-lived microtubules, and that the formation of a rigid perinuclear microtubule cage is a structural mechanism used by migratory cells to protect the nucleus from mechanical damage during transit through constricted environments.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that mechanical confinement triggers a specific cytoskeletal adaptation where cells stabilize their microtubules to form a protective cage around the nucleus, thereby imparting the structural resilience necessary to support a neuronal-like, invasive phenotype.
